Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a 400 MHz Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectrometer for the Advancement of Research and Teaching at Texas A&M International University
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program that is co-funded by the Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) Program, Professor Alfred Addo-Mensah from Texas A&M International University (TAMUI) and colleagues Anju Gupta, Eugenio Jaramillo, Qingwen Ni and James Cohen will acquire a 400 MHz NMR spectrometer to be housed at TAMUI but also accesible to Laredo Community College (LCC). This award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) design, synthesis, characterization and binding studies of multivalent bipyridine based macrocyclic carbohydrate receptors in aqueous solutions; (b) evolutionary patterns, identification, and characterization of naphthoquinones in the plant family boraginaceae; (c) study of molecular sieves containing transition metal ions; and (d) design and synthesis of light-emitting polymers.

Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The results from these NMR studies will have an impact in synthetic organic/inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument will be an integral part of teaching as well as research at both of these minority serving institutions, which will increase access to modern instrumentation to a large number of underrepresented students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Bruker 400 MHz AVANCE NMR Spectrometer acquired under this project has been instrumental in the execution of many projects, developed new areas of research, development of new synthetic pathways to help synthesize new analogs, develop faculty competence in maintaining and troubleshooting NMR, develop both undergraduate and graduate students to explore new areas of research, incorporate research in teaching chemistry thereby developing enduring learning experiences. Multiple research questions are being pursued because of the versatility of the instrument purchased which has opened the research domains of faculty currently using the machine.

Capability to fully characterize synthesized molecules in a multi-step synthesis and isolated natural products: One of the aims of the project was to synthesize and characterize carbohydrate receptors and test binding using spectroscopic means including the NMR. This multi-step synthesis has been successful. Preliminary results have been presented in conferences and a graduate thesis will be presented to the graduate school of Texas A&M International in December 2016 by a graduating student. The importance of multiple hydrogen bonding in carbohydrate recognition have been discovered in the preliminary data and will serve as hypothesis for developing further receptors towards achieving stronger binding of lectin mimics in aqueous media. The synthetic pathway created allows researchers to design analogs for structure activity relationship studies with the aim to better understand lectin-carbohydrate interactions. In a research designed to discover anti-bacterial drug, 7 final compounds were prepared from a 9 step synthesis.  Each intermediate in the sequence was characterized by 1H NMR using the Bruker AVANCE 400 NMR.  Prior attempts to complete this synthesis without intermediate characterization were not successful. Current studies involve determining the kinetic and thermodynamic properties of a novel epoxide to furan rearrangement.  An Undergraduate student developed a synthesis for a compound that was used to prepare an anti-bacterial compound that has very potent activity against an NTM organism that has no effective therapy.  This compound is going to be scaled up for animal testing.  This work and 1H NMR spectra were presented at an internal research symposium in the Spring of 2016. The preliminary results in the synthesis of NTM anti-bacterial drugs will be submitted as an NIH R15 grant which is only possible with the characterization capabilities provided by the Bruker Avance 400 NMR. There should be enough data to publish several papers based on the data generated by the Bruker AVANCE 400 NMR within the next year to 18 months. Compounds isolated from extract of natural products known to have significant bioactivity have been characterized. Preliminary results have generated hypothesis to seek extra funding through the NIH R15 grant in February 2017.  All of these projects (current and future) require the analytical capabilities of the Bruker AVANCE 400 NMR spectrometer.

Enhancement of Teaching and Undergraduate Research: In active learning laboratory experiments the acquisition of the Bruker 400 MHz NMR has allowed us to design experiments that produce enduring learning. Instead of students being supplied with ‘unknown compounds’ to characterize they isolate their own compounds and characterize by NMR. The exercise is both frustrating and rewarding for them but that is the reality of science. A Physical Chemistry class used the Bruker variable temperature capabilities to prepare an Arrhenius plot to measure the rotation barrier of an amide bond.  The practice of designing and executing experiments also helps prepares students for life in graduate school or in an industrial research and development setting. Two student undergraduate posters will be submitted for presentation at the American Chemical Society meeting in the Spring of 2017 and students will present data generated using the Bruker AVANCE 400 NMR.  This instrument coupled with others has helped provide quality holistic chemistry education for minority students. This will help bridge the gap of minorities in science.

Human resource development: Graduate and undergraduate students employed as interns, research assistants and managers have been trained with vital skills that will help them succeed in the scientific workforce. Some have actually been encouraged to pursue graduate programs in organic chemistry and analytical chemistry. A pipeline for training/developing the next generation minority scientist has been created. Students whose project depended on characterization have completed their research. The generation of preliminary data which has been presented at conferences has boosted the interests of students to pursue further education. Two graduate students are doing research that is directly depended on using the NMR for characterization and kinetic studies.
